meanings.def: to fasten something with a lock; to be fastened with a lock
examples: Did you lock the door?
David locked the car and slipped the key into his pocket.
The gates are locked at 6 o'clock.
a locked cabinet
This suitcase doesn't lock.
Keep your garage securely locked.
The door locks automatically.

meanings.def: to put something in a safe place and lock it
examples: She locked her passport and money in the safe.

meanings.def: to become or make something become fixed in one position and unable to move
examples: The brakes locked and the car skidded.
He locked his helmet into position with a click.

meanings.def: to be involved in a difficult situation, an argument, etc.
examples: The two sides are locked into a bitter dispute.
She felt locked in a loveless marriage.

meanings.def: to be held very tightly by somebody
examples: They were locked in a passionate embrace.

meanings.def: to use a code or password to prevent data on a phone or computer from being changed or looked at by somebody without permission
examples: These files are locked to protect confidentiality.
My phone is locked and I've forgotten the password.
Make sure you lock your screen if you leave your desk.

meanings.def: to get involved in an argument with somebody
examples: The company has locked horns with the unions over proposed pay cuts.

idioms.def: to get involved in an argument with somebody
examples: The company has locked horns with the unions over proposed pay cuts.

meanings.def: a device that keeps a door, window, box, etc. shut, usually needing a key to open it
examples: She turned the key in the lock.
It's a good idea to have locks fitted on all your windows.
Most cars are now fitted with child safety locks on the back doors.
She ran around the house, checking all the locks.
The hotels replaced their mortise locks on guest rooms with magnetic card readers.
They changed the locks on the doors and windows.

meanings.def: a device that prevents a vehicle, machine or piece of equipment from being used
examples: a bicycle lock
a steering lock
safety locks for handguns

meanings.def: a feature on a computer or mobile phone that prevents somebody from accessing it without a code
examples: There's a security lock on the phone.

meanings.def: a state in which the parts of a machine, etc. do not move
the amount that the front wheels can be turned in one direction or the other in order to turn the vehicle
examples: I had the steering wheel on full lock (= I had turned it as far as it would turn).

meanings.def: a section of canal or river with a gate at either end, in which the water level can be changed so that boats can move from one level of the canal or river to another
a few hairs that hang or lie together on your head
examples: John brushed a lock of hair from his eyes.
She kept a lock of her mother’s hair.

meanings.def: a person’s hair
examples: She shook her long, flowing locks.

meanings.def: a player in the second row of the scrum
total control of something
examples: One company had a virtual lock on all orange juice sales in the state.

meanings.def: including everything
examples: He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

meanings.def: to open a lock without a key, using something such as a piece of wire
examples: The burglars must have picked the lock on the back door.

meanings.def: locked up safely somewhere; in prison
examples: We keep our valuables under lock and key.
I will not rest until the murderer is under lock and key.
Prisoners are kept under lock and key 24 hours a day.
He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

idioms.def: to open a lock without a key, using something such as a piece of wire
examples: The burglars must have picked the lock on the back door.

idioms.idiom: (keep something/put something/be) under lock and key
idioms.def: locked up safely somewhere; in prison
examples: We keep our valuables under lock and key.
I will not rest until the murderer is under lock and key.
